What does this mean?
This page was created and managed using Blogger [www.blogger.com].  
You are looking at an offline copy, stripped of identities and some links.
This is made available for use in Staff Development and dissemination within the UK FE and ACL community (Project part-funded and sponsored by LSDA - Learning and Skills Development Agency).The live blog is located at http://www.viewtheQ.blogspot.com
 

African & Caribbean Resource Centre (ACRC)

ACRC is a community based mental health service which promotes independence, choice and general well being of its service users. This is a project for students with the College of North West London. The idea is to post pictures and descriptions of the students to this blog, and so create a class website.

Wednesday, January 18, 2006

As a next stage in entering the blogosphere, ACRC users now have their own blog sites. To check them out, visit:

  • Skip's Poetry Corner
  • Raffy's World
  • Danny's blog
More to come...?

Wednesday, January 11, 2006

Who Am I: N****** S*****
What I Do: Train horses and do computer classes
Likes: Healing, spirituality, creative writing and food
Dislikes: Rude people
My Dream: To go to Heaven
My Reality: Life is boring and sometimes gets worse. I feel bad due to the side effects of my medication.

I am trying to get fit by walking, cycling and doing weights. Doing physical exercise helps me feel a lot better. I also am very lucky as I have a loving and supportive family.

Poetry by skip

'Sun turn by day moon by night
why people of fuss and fight
dont worry about thing
every little thing gone be alright
in day or night.'
Two other organisations which I think are useful to know about are:
BUG -A mental health group. Provides advise and information on issues regarding mental health .They visit and assist clients who are in hospital or have left to cope.
Brent Mind - organisation for mental health issues in the local borough. I am a member and we have meetings and invite people to give talk about recent
developments such as the green paper and other issues that could affect people in Brent with mental health concerns.
MALCOLM X
And you dare to call me coloured...
"When I'm born I'm black, when I grow up I'm black, when I'm the cold I'm black,
when I'm in the sun I'm black, when I'm sick I'm black, when I die I'm black .
And you when you're born you're pink , when you grow up you're White ,
when you're cold you're Blue, when you're in the sun you're Red, when you're sick you're Green, when you die you're purple. And dare to call ME a coloured....".
THOUGHTS
If we understood the power of our thoughts ,
we would guard them more closely.
If we under prefer silence to almost anything
negative.
In our thoughts and words we create
Our own weaknesses and our own strengths.
Our limitations and joys begin in our hearts.
We can alway replace negative with positive.
Betty Eadie

ACRC Blog Website Project

Students are all referrals from Social Services and have varying levels of mental health issues. What I try to do, is to encourage participation and motivate students to attend regularly; to feel relaxed and confident and use the computer without any stress. All students are able to type using Microsoft Word. Some students have setup their own email accounts, and we use the internet to research many topics that they are interested in.

Students have been enthusiastic about using the Blog, and it has been a very useful tool to aid learning and has been easily encorporated as part of ongoing Information Learning Technology (ILT) training. From onset, it has been well received by all students who have found it an enjoyable experience. It is a positive route to demonstrate progression and reinforce previous learning. We are updating the ACRC Blog website regularly and ACRC workers and students have many ideas of how to expand and use this website which will benefit many people with mental health issues, provide advice and widen knowledge and understanding.

posted by CNWL Outreach @ 11:36 AM   0 comments  

Friday, November 25, 2005



Who Am I: I'm Tony
What I Do: I drone on and on about how important all this e-learning stuff is, and how it can maybe empower students to engage actively with their studies, and how it doesn't replace teaching but somehow adds to it and, err, enriches it, and how using the Internet and computers can open up a whole world of possibilities that, hey c'mon, students will explore anyway so their teachers better get themselves on board and able to work with, and on and on ....

Links

    The following are a few sites of interest or relevance to ACRC users....
  • Brent Council Homepage
  • Jobcentre plus - help and advice on jobs and training
  • DWP website - information if you are looking for work
  • NHS Gateway
  • Mencap - Understanding learning disability
  • Mind (National Association for Mental Health)
  • College of North West London - website
  • CNWL Online - students only
